_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.)  General accidental release and prevention policy of Northeast Refrigerated Terminals, Inc..

       Northeast Refrigerated Terminals, Inc. is a cold storage warehousing facility that utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a    
       refrigerant.

       Anhydrous Ammonia is considered hazardous by the Environmental Protection Agency and the same properties that
       make ammonia a valuable refrigerant also makes it necessary to observe certain safety precautions.

       To prevent exposure to our workers, surrounding community and the environment, it is our policy to implement the
       requirements of the Risk Management Program by:

               1.  Managing and operating this facility in full compliance with all applicable federal and state regulations that we are
                    governed by.  The objective is to minimize the risk of an accidental release of hazardous materials.

               2.  Our plant personnel have been trained on the equipment operating procedures and various safety devices, which
                    are incorporated in our facility to prevent the possibility of an accidental release.

               3.  Key employees have been trained to isolate areas within the refrigeration system, which may become hazardous.

               4.  These employees have attended the 24 hr. Emergency Response Training in Ammonia Refrigeration and will 
                    attend the eight (8) hour refresher course annually.

               5.  Safety depends on our proper handling of Anhydrous Ammonia in this facility and Northeast Refrigerated Terminals,
                    Inc. will ensure that the safety of its employees comes first.

2.)  Stationary source and regulated substance handled at:

      Northeast Refrigerated Terminals, Inc.
      97 Wood Street
      Middleboro, MA  02346

      Operates a refrigerations system utilizing Anhydrous Ammonia as the primary refrigerant.

      Mechanical refrigeration is a thermodynamic process where t

he refrigerant ammonia is used as a heat exchanging fluid to
      maintain a desired temperature in an enclosed environment.

      The refrigeration cycle consists of evaporation, compression, condensation and expansion.

      Evaporation and condensation are designed to alter the quantity of energy associated with the refrigerant.

      Compression and expansion are designed to change the availability of the associated energy.

      The refrigeration cycle is a closed loop system.

      The ammonia cycle utilizes fluid temperature, pressure and latent heat of vaporization for cooling.

      The refrigeration system uses this phenomenon to remove heat from a desired space and then to discard that heat through
      condensation to an area where it is of no consequence.

Northeast Refrigerated Terminals, Inc. operates the refrigeration room consisting of compressors, condensers, pump receivers,
and coil evaporators.  These items are used to maintain the freezer and holding room temperatures required for the process and
storage of our product.

There are approximately 10 employees at this facility, including hourly and salary personnel, who prepare shipment of frozen
product.

Our operation is one shift of eight hours per day, five days per week.  Our refrigeration system operates 24 hours per day, seven
days a week in order to maintain temperatures with our cold storage freezers.

The refrigeration system contains approximately 10,000 pounds of aggregate ammonia.  The potential hazards that could lead
to an accidental release of ammonia include, but are not limited to:

     Equipment failure, damage to piping, damage to equipment, human error, etc.  Although ammonia is a colorless, tasteless,
     liquid, it's dominate characteristic is it's pungent distinct odor.

     Persons exposed to ammonia will not voluntarily stay in areas of even small concentrations, although these levels would not 
     normally result in any heath risks.  Risks from accidental exp

osure to ammonia in a vapor state are irritations to the eyes,  
     nose and throat.

     The extent of irritations depends on the exposure amount and length of time exposed.  Ammonia will burn, but only in a very
     concentration level when accompanied with a constant ignition source.

     The Department of Transportation classifies ammonia as non-flammable.

Worst-case and alternate case release scenarios including administrative and engineering controls to limit/prevent accidental
release.

Worst-case scenario depicts continous source leak from the Low Pressure Pump Receiver located in the Engine Room.

     Would require evacuations of all employees except trained ammonia emergency response personnel.

     Although these employees are not required to repair any damaged area, they would be capable of entering the refrigeration
     room with Scott-air packs (SCBA) to isolate certain areas within the refrigeration room.

     They would hit Emergency Shut Down Button of King Value.

Any employee overcome with an exposure from ammonia will be given immediate medical assistance.  Company trained first aid
and CPR attendants will assist individual until qualified medical help arrives.

Worst-case release scenario criteria for Northeast Refrigerated Terminals, Inc. facility:

Ammonia Quantity: 10,000 pounds.

               Rate of Releasse: 500h/min
    
               LOC (Level of Concern):  30ppm

               Physical State:  Gas

               Type of Area:  Urban

               Wind Speed:  3.4 mph

               Distance of Endpoint:  5.9 miles

Alternate release scenario is represented by the release of ammonia vapor from a safety relief valve (SRV) due to an over
pressuriztion condition on the condensing tower located on the roof.

The indicated relief valve would be preforming exactly as it is designed to do during an over pressurized condition.  Valve would 
open to relieve the pressure and vent it to the atmosphere.



The following administra

tive and engineering controls are in place at Northeast Refrigerated Terminals, Inc.

These controls are designed to eliminate, or reduce the possiblities of an accidental release.

     Electronic ammonia detection system has been installed in the refrigeration room.

     Alarm system activates visual alarm to alert plant personnel of the potential ammonia leak in the monitored area.  System
     will alert proper personnel in the event of detection above 25ppm and which zone has triggered the alarm.  The ammonia
     detection system is tied into local alarm compnay and is monitored 24 hrs each day.

     Power will be cut off to solenoid valve on liquid line feeding vessel causing the high level.

     All compressors are configured with critical safety controls (high pressure, low pressure, high oil temp cutouts, etc) to shut 
     down the respective compressor in the event of an adnormal operating condition.

     Safety relief valves are configured to all pressure vessels, condensers and compressor oil separators to eliminate over 
     pressurization conditions in those associated pieces of equipment.

     Periodic Maintenance Program is in place within the Northeast maintenance management program to ensure the
     refrigeration system and its components are kept in optimum mechanical and operating status.

     Daily and weekly rounds are made by plant personnel to verify proper equipment operation.

Northeast maintenace management checks the refrigeration system on weekends for any signs of malfunction.
